Association: CYP2C19 *2 + *3 is associated with decreased metabolism of diazepam as compared to CYP2C19 *1.
More Details: Subjects were treated with diazepam to reduce preoperative anxiety. Subjects were classified as extensive metabolizers (*1/*1 genotype), intermediate metabolizers (*1/*2 or *1/*3 genotype), and poor metabolizers (*2/*2, *2/*3, *3/*3 genotype, though no subjects with the *3/*3 genotype were found in this study). Poor metabolizers showed significantly increased diazepam AUC and decreased diazepam clearance as compared to extensive metabolizers. Poor metabolizers and intermediate metabolizers also showed significantly longer time to emerge from anesthesia as compared to extensive metabolizers.

Association: CYP2C19 intermediate metabolizers is not associated with dose of diazepam in people with Alcohol Withdrawal Delirium and Alcohol Withdrawal Seizures as compared to CYP2C19 normal metabolizer.
More Details: Dose refers to loading dose. Intermediate metabolizers were categorized as individuals with the *2/*17, *1/*2 or *1/*3 genotypes.

Association: Genotype AG is associated with Drug Toxicity when treated with diazepam and phenytoin in children with Epilepsy.
More Details: in a single case. Plasma phenytoin levels were higher than expected (69 mgL(-1); normal range: 10-20 mgL(-1))

Association: CYP2C19 ultrarapid metabolizer is not associated with dose of diazepam in people with Alcohol Withdrawal Delirium and Alcohol Withdrawal Seizures as compared to CYP2C19 normal metabolizer.
More Details: Dose refers to loading dose. Ultra rapid metabolizers were categorized as individuals with the *1/*17, *17/*17 genotypes.

Association: CYP2C9 *2/*2 is associated with Drug Toxicity when treated with diazepam and phenytoin in children with Epilepsy.
More Details: in a single case. Plasma phenytoin levels were higher than expected (69 mgL(-1); normal range: 10-20 mgL(-1))
